questions.text: Which of the following steps of disaster management is in correct order?
questions.solution:
The correct order is: Disaster impact – Response – Rehabilitation – Mitigation

  • Disaster impact and response includes:
    • Search, rescue and first aid must be done first.
    • Field care
    • Triage
    • Lagging
    • Identification of dead
  • Rehabilitation or recovery includes:
    • Water supply
    • Sanitation and personal hygiene
    • Food safety
    • Vector control
  • Mitigation:
    • Measures designed to either prevent hazards or reduce the effects of the disaster leading to disaster preparedness.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false under the National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme?

choices.text: Continuation phase for new sputum smear positive: HRE for 16 weeks
Intensive phase for sputum smear positive after loss to follow up: HRZE for 8 weeks
Continuation phase for sputum smear positive recurrent case: HRE for 16 weeks
Intensive phase for sputum smear positive after failure to treatment: HRZES for 12 weeks

questions.solution:
Under National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP) guidelines Initiation phase (IP) for both new and previously treated cases which are H and R sensitive is HRZE for 8 weeks.

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments
H mono-resistant/ poly-drug resistant TB regimen Lfx R E Z for 6 months

6 months long

Oral drugs only
BPaLM regime (New MDR regime by WHO) Bdq Pa Lzd Mfx for 6 months

6 months long
9- 11 months shorter oral bedaquiline regime (Shorter MDR)

Intensive Phase:

Lfx Bdq(6 months) Cfz Z Hh E Eto for 4-6 months

Continuation phase:

Lfx Cfz Z E for 5 months

9-11 months long totally

Injectables used in Intensive phase.
Longer MDR TB regimen Bdq(6 months or longer) Lfx Lzd Cfz Cs 

18-20 months long

Oral drugs only

This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.

 

Criteria for patients to receive standard Drug Resistant TB regimen:

Standard Drug Resistant TB regimen Inclusion criteria Exclusion criteria
H mono-resistant/poly-drug resistant TB regimen Isoniazid resistant TB with rifampicin sensitive No specific criteria
BPaLM regimen (New MDR TB regimen by WHO)
  1. MDR/RR-TB or pre-XDR-TB ( MDR/RR-TB and resistance to fluoroquinolones). 
  2. Those with confirmed pulmonary TB and all forms of extrapulmonary TB (except for TB involving CNS, osteoarticular, and miliary TB).
  3. Patients >14 years of age.
 Pregnant and lactating women
9- 11 months shorter MDR TB regimen Patient with rifampicin resistant pulmonary or extra pulmonary TB Non drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • Pregnancy
  • Any extra pulmonary disease in PLHIV
  • Disseminated meningeal or central nervous system TB
  • Intolerance to any drug in the shorter MDR TB regimen
Drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • If DST/DRT result for FQ or SLI is resistant (XDR TB)
  • Presence of InhA mutation
  • Resistant to Z 
Longer MDR TB regimen Patients in whom shorter MDR TB regimen cannot be considered due to any reason None

Legend

FQ: Fluoroquinolone

SLI: Second Line Injectable

PLHIV: People Living with HIV

Lfx: Levofloxacin

Pa: Pretomanid

H: Isoniazid

Hh: High Dose Isoniazid

R: Rifampicin

E: Ethambutol

Z: Pyrazinamide

Mfx: Moxifloxacin

Km: Kanamycin

Am: Amikacin

Eto: Ethionamide

Cfz: Clofazimine

Bdq: Bedaquiline

Lzd: Linezolid

Cs: Cycloserine

questions.text: IQ in profound mental retardation will be:
questions.solution:
Intelligence Quotient (IQ)

  • When the mental age is same as that of chronological age IQ will be 100.
  • First intelligence tests were developed by: Binet and Simon (1896).
  • Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale (WAIS): David Wechsler (1939) published the first intelligence test designed for an adult population; It was the first IQ test based on Normal/ Gaussian distribution.

 Levels of Intelligence based on IQ level:

Levels of intelligence IQ
Idiot 0-24
Imbecile 24-49
Moron 50-69
Borderline 70-79
Low normal 80-89
Normal 90-109
Superior 110-119
Very superior 120-139
Near genius 140 and over

Categories of mental retardation based on IQ levels:

Mental status IQ range
Normal IQ 70 and over
Mild mental retardation 50-69
Moderate mental retardation 35-49
Severe mental retardation 21-34
Profound mental retardation 20 or below

questions.text: Which of the following indicators is the best to know the overall burden of disease?
questions.solution:
• DALY is the best measure of overall burden of a disease in a defined population and effectiveness of interventions.
  • It can measure both mortality and disability together.
  • DALY = Years of lost life (YLL) + Years lost of disability (YLD)

questions.text: All of the following are features of problem village except:

choices.text: No source of safe water within a distance of 1.6Km
Water is available at a depth of more than 15 metres
Water is exposed to the risk of dracunculiasis
Water source has excess salinity, iron, fluorides and other toxic elements

questions.solution:
Problem village does not include the exposure of water to the risk of dracunculiasis.

Problem village:

  • No source of safe water within a distance of 1.6 Km. 
  • Water is available at a depth of more than 15 m. 
  • Water source has excess salinity, iron, fluorides and other toxic elements.
  • Water is exposed to the risk of Cholera.

questions.text: Learned behavior which is socially acquired is known as?
questions.solution:
Culture:

  • Is the learned behavior which is socially acquired.

Other options:

Option A  - Custom:

  • The established patterns of behavior that can be objectively verified within a particular social setting.

Option B - Acculturation: Is ‘cultural contact’ or mixing of two cultures. It can occur through:

  • Trade and commerce
  • Industrialization
  • Propagation of religion
  • Education
  • Conquest

Option C  - Standard of Living:

  • Refers to the usual scale of our expenditure, goods we consume and the services we enjoy.
  • Standard of living (WHO) includes: 
    • Income and Occupation
    • Standards of housing, sanitation, and nutrition
    • Level of provision of health, educational, recreational and other services

Folkways:

  • Right ways of doing things in less vital areas of human conduct.
  • Mores are stringent customs.

questions.text: To attain the two-child norm, the net reproductive rate to be obtained is:
questions.solution:
The Net Reproductive Ratio signifies the number of daughters a new born girl will bear in her lifetime assuming fixed age specific fertility and mortality rates.

  • NRR is a demographic indicator
  • NRR of India is 1.5 (1990) 
  • NRR of 1 is equivalent to approximately attaining 2 child norm in India.

questions.text: Arrange the following stages of a family cycle in chronological order:

choices.text: Formation, Extension, Complete extension, Dissolution, Contraction, Complete contraction
Formation, Extension, Contraction, Complete extension, Complete contraction, Dissolution
Formation, Contraction, Complete contraction, Extension, Complete extension, Dissolution
Formation, Extension, Complete extension, Contraction, Complete contraction, Dissolution

questions.solution:
Family cycle has 6 phases in the order of:

Phases of family lifecycle  Beginning of phase End of phase
Formation Marriage Birth of the 1st child
Extenssion Birth of the 1st child Birth of last child
Complete extension Birth of last child 1st child leaves home
Contraction 1st child leaves home Last child leaves home
Completed contraction Last child leaves home 1st spouse dies
Dissolution 1st spouse dies Death of survivuor

questions.text: Which of the following is not a socio-pathological factor associated with mental health?
questions.solution:
Causes of mental health disorders:

  • Organic: Cerebral arteriosclerosis, neoplasm, endocrine, metabolic and chronic diseases
  • Heredity: Schizophrenia
  • Socio-pathological: Worries, anxiety, frustration, poverty, abuse, neglect etc.
  • Environmental: Substance abuse, toxicities and infectious diseases like rubella

questions.text: In India, the level of iodization is fixed at?

choices.text: Not less than 30 ppm at production point and not less than 15ppm at consumer level
Not less than 30 ppm at production and at consumer level
Not less than 15 ppm at production point and at consumer level
Not less than 50 ppm at production point and not less than 25 ppm at consumer

questions.solution:
In India, the level of iodization is fixed at not less than 30 ppm at production point and not less than 15 ppm at the consumer level.

  • The best source of Iodine are sea foods(sea salt, sea fish).
  • Daily requirement of Iodine for adults is 150 mcg/d.
  • Daily requirement of Iodine during pregnancy is 250 mcg/d.
  • 2 in 1 salt is common salt fortified with iron and iodine 1 ml of Iodized oil injection will give protection for 4 years.

The interference with Iodine utilization by the thyroid gland is caused by goitrogens. The brassica group of vegetables (cabbage, cauliflower) contains goitrogens. Most important dietary goitrogens are cyanoglycosides and thiocyanates.

Neonatal hypothyroidism is a sensitive indicator of environmental iodine deficiency and thus an effective indicator for monitoring the impact of a programme.

questions.text: Who or which of the following is known as the ‘Father of Public Health’?
questions.solution:
Father of Public Health is the cholera disease, not a person.

Other options:

  • Tuberculosis is called the barometer of social welfare.
  • John Snow is called the father of modern epidemiology. He studied the epidemiology of cholera and established the role of polluted drinking water in the spread of cholera.
  • Louis Pasteur is the father of modern microbiology.

Related Pearl: History of Microbiology

 Achievement  Scientist
Father of Microscopy/Microbiology Anton von Leeuwenhoek   
Father of Modern Microbiology Louis Pasteur   
Father of Bacteriology Robert Koch  
Father of Virology W M Stanley   
Father of Mycology Raymond Sabouraud  
Father of Chemotherapy Paul Ehrlich  
Father of Antiseptic surgery Joseph Lister   
Founder of Electron Microscope Ernst Ruska  
Founder of L forms of Bacteria Kleinberger   
Founder of Gram Stain Hans Christian Gram 
First to describe phagocytosis Elie Metchnikoff  
Founder of PCR Karry B Mullis

questions.text: When the level of hardness of water is around 150-300 mg/L, it is classified as?
questions.solution:
Hard water has the hardness value of 3–6 (150–300 mg/ L).

The hardness of water is defined as soap destroying power of water.

  • Causes of Hardness of water: 
    • Calcium bicarbonate 
    • Magnesium bicarbonate 
    • Calcium sulphate 
    • Magnesium sulphate 
  • Hardness can be either:
    • Temporary hardness- caused by carbonates compounds 
    • Permanent hardness- caused by non carbonate compounds like sulphates, nitrates and chlorides
  • It is expressed in terms of mEq/ L.  
  • 1mEq/ L of hardness = 50 mg CaCO3  in one liter of water. 

Classification Level of Hardness (mEq/ L) 

Classification Level of Hardness  mEq/ L
Soft water < 1 (50 mg/ L)
Moderately hard water 1-3 (50-150 mg/ L)
Hard water 3-6 (150-300 mg/ L)
Very hard water > 6 (>300 mg/ L)

Softening of water is recommended at level of hardness >3 mEq/ L (>150 mg/ L of calcium carbonate).

questions.text: Population genetics is related to:
questions.solution:
• Population genetics is the study of precise genetic composition of a population and various factors determining the incidence of inherited traits in them. 
  • The Hardy-Weinberg Law is related to population genetics.
  • It is based on the principle founded by G.H. Hardy and Wilhelm Weinberg. 
  • The law states that the relative frequencies of each gene allele, tends to remain constant from generation to generation in absence of other evolutionary influences. 
  • It is also called the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium or principle.     
  • It is only applicable for infinitely large, static populations which randomly mate. 
  • This law fails in the following conditions:
    • Small and dynamic populations
    • Non random or assortative mating
    • Mutations
    • Gene outflow and genetic drift
    • Migration

questions.text: Metallic body implants are disposed off in which colored bags?
questions.solution:
Metallic body implants and glassware are disposed off in Blue colored bags.

Related Pearl: Biomedical waste disposal

 

  Yellow bag (non-chlorinated)  

Type of Waste

  Treatment and Disposal Options

Human anatomical waste

Animal anatomical waste

Incineration/Plasma pyrolysis/Deep Burial
Soiled Waste: Items like dressings, cotton swabs, and plaster casts contaminated with blood and body fluids and bags containing residual discarded blood.

Incineration/Plasma pyrolysis/Deep Burial

or

Autoclaving/Microwaving/ Hydroclaving

Later - Shredding/mutilation
Discarded linen, mattresses, beddings contaminated with blood or body fluid, routine masks, and gowns

Non- chlorinated chemical disinfection
followed by incineration or Plazma
Pyrolysis or for energy recovery.
In absence of the above facilities, shredding, mutilation, or a combination of sterilization and shredding is used.

Microbiology, biotechnology, clinical laboratory waste

(Autoclave safe plastic bags used)

Blood bags, laboratory
cultures, stocks or specimens of microorganisms,
live or attenuated vaccines, human and animal cell cultures used in research, industrial laboratories, production of biological, residual toxins, dishes, and devices used for cultures.

Pre-treatment with nonchlorinated chemicals

Later - Incineration

Expired/discarded medicine, cytotoxic drugs

 Incineration/plasma pyrolysis/ disposal in a secured landfill
 

Chemical waste

Chemicals used in biological production and used or discarded
disinfectants.

Disposal- incineration/plasma
pyrolysis

Encapsulation- hazardous waste treatment, storage, and disposal facility.

Chemical liquid waste :
Liquid waste generated due to the use of chemicals in the production of
biological and used or discarded disinfectants, silver X-ray film
developing liquid,
discarded formalin,
infected secretions,
aspirated body fluids, liquid from laboratories and floor washings, cleaning, house-keeping and
disinfecting activities etc.

 

 After resource recovery, the chemical
liquid waste shall be pre-treated before mixing with other wastewater. 

 

  Red bag (non-chlorinated)  
 Type of Waste

 Treatment and Disposal Options

Recyclable contaminated waste

Contaminated waste tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles and fixed needle syringes with their needles cut), vacutainers with needles cut, and gloves.

Autoclaving/Microwaving/
Hydroclaving

Followed by Shredding/mutilation

And later, Energy recovery/Plastics to diesel or fuel oil/road-making

Not to be sent to landfill

 

  White (translucent)  
(puncture-proof, leak-proof containers)
Type of Waste

Treatment and Disposal Options

Waste Sharps including metals.

Needles, syringes with fixed needles, needles from needle tip cutter or burner, scalpels, blades, or any other contaminated sharp object that may cause puncture and cuts. This includes both used, discarded, and contaminated metal sharps

Autoclaving/ Dry heat sterilization

Followed by - Shredding/mutilation/
encapsulation

Later by - Iron foundries/sanitary landfill/waste sharps

 

   Blue  
(Puncture proof and leak proof containers with blue colored marking)

Type of Waste 

 Treatment and Disposal Options

Glassware

Broken or discarded and contaminated glass including medicine vials and ampules except those containing cytotoxic waste.

Metallic body implants

Sodium hypochlorite/Autoclaving/
Microwaving/Hydroclaving

Later - Recycling

 

 Note: Ash from the incineration of biomedical waste shall be disposed of at a common hazardous waste treatment and disposal facility. However, it may also be disposed of in a municipal landfill, if the toxic metals in incineration ash are within the regulatory quantities as defined under the Hazardous Waste (Management and Handling and Transboundary Movement) Rules, 2008 as amended from time to time.

questions.text: At which level of heat stress index it is not possible to work comfortably causing threat to health?
questions.solution:
Heat stress index of 40-60 is not comfortable to work as it may be a threat to health. Heat stress is the burden or load of heat that must be dissipated if the body is to remain in thermal equilibrium.

Heat stress indices include:

  • Equatorial comfort index
  • Heat stress index
  • Predicted four hour sweat rate

Heat Stress Indices values:

HSI Consequence of 8 hr exposure
0 No thermal strains
10-30 Mild-moderate heat stress, minimal impairment in work
40-60 Severe heat stress.Threat to life if not fit
70-90 Very severe heat stress, only few can sustain it
100 Maximum heat stress, only young fit can sustain it
>100 Varying degree of stress due to hyperthermia

questions.text: A village has a population of 30,000 people. 300 of them have a disease, out of which 30 people died. What is the case fatality rate?
questions.solution:
Case fatality rate:

  • It is a good indicator of severity or killing power of a disease.
  • It is used mostly in acute and infectious diseases.
  • No time interval is used.
  • Case fatality rate is closely related to virulence.
  • Limitation of CFR is that its usefulness is limited in chronic diseases.
  • It is expressed in percentage.
  • CFR is an incidence proportion and not a true rate.
  • CFR may vary for the same disease in different epidemics.

Case fatality rate = Total number of deaths due to a particular disease/Total number of cases due to the same disease x100

questions.text: Under ESI scheme, the employer's contribution is:
questions.solution:
The employer contributes 3.25% of the total wages bill.

The ESI Act, 1948:

  • Covers all power using factories wherein 10 or more persons were employed (excluding railways, mines, and defense establishments).
  • From 2016 the act covers all employees getting up to 21,000 per month.

Finance:

  • The employee contributes 0.75% of total wages.
  • The employer contributes 3.25% of the total wages bill.
  • An employee getting daily wages below 100 are exempted from contribution.
  • The state government's share is 1/8th of the total cost of medical care.
  • The ESI corporation's share is 7/8th of the total cost of medical care.

Sickness benefit:

  • For a maximum period of 91 days in a year, 70% of average daily wages given.
  • Extended sickness benefit for a maximum period of 2 years for the 34 chronic diseases.
  • Cash benefit for insured people in productive age group undergoing sterilization
    • Enhanced sickness benefit to women for 14 days for tubectomy.
    • 7 days to men for the vasectomy.
    • The amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate (100% of wages).

questions.text: A temporary and provisional view held by people on a point of debate is:
questions.solution:
Opinions:

  • Views held by people on a point of dispute.
  • They are temporary and provisional.
  • They are subjective in nature.

Different types of views:

Terms Feature
Opinions Temporary, provisional, subjective, views held at a point dispute
Attitude Permanent, its caught not taught, objective, relatively enduring
Value The idol, customs, institution of a society towards the people of the group have an effective regard 
Belief Views derived from parents, permanent, unstable and subjective

questions.text: In comparing the mortality experience of two countries, standardization of rates is done due to differences in:
questions.solution:
• Standardization is done to compare the death rate of two populations with different age composition.
  • This adjustment can be done for sex, race etc.
  • Two types: direct and indirect standardization.
  • In both methods, a standard population is chosen.
  • Standard population is a population where numbers in each age and sex group are known and its choice is arbitrary.
  • Commonly used standard populations are Segi world population and European standard population.

questions.text: Cluster testing is useful in detecting cases of
questions.solution:
Cluster testing is an intervention strategy in the control of STDs.

Control of STDs: The intervention strategies to control STDs are:

  • Case detection
    • Screening
    • Contact tracing- Sexual partners of identified patients are diagnosed and treated
    • Cluster testing- Patients asked to name other people of either sex who move in the same socio-sexual environment
  • Case holding and treatment
  • Epidemiological treatment
  • Personal prophylaxis
  • Health education

questions.text: Poverty line in urban areas is defined as expenditure required for daily calorie consumption below?
questions.solution:
Poverty line is defined as the expenditure required for a daily calorie intake of:

  • 2100 per person per day in urban areas.
  • 2400 per person pe dayin rural areas.

questions.text: In a village having a population of 5000, a diagnostic test for a particular disease showed the following results. What is the prevalence of the disease?
questions.solution:
• In this scenario, total number of diseases cases is 1500 and total population at risk is 5000, thus making the prevalence 30%.
  • Prevalence is the proportion of all cases (old and new) of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population.
  • It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. It can be determined from cross sectional studies.
  • Types are:
    • Point prevalence:
      • It is the prevalence at a point in time.
      • Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.
    • Period prevalence:
      • It is the prevalence over a period of time.

Prevalence =( Number of all cases (old+new) of a specified disease at a given point in time/Estimated population at the same point in time ) x 100

  • It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the Vandematharam scheme?

choices.text: Its aim is to provide safe motherhood services
An MBBS graduate or an obstetrician can volunteer
IFA tablets and TT injections are provided by District Medical Officers

questions.solution:
The Vandematharam scheme does not include free treatment in private clinics.

Vandematharam scheme is a voluntary scheme for providing safe motherhood services. It can be volunteered by an obstetrician, maternity home, nursing home, lady doctor or an MBBS graduate.

IFA tablets, OCPs, and TT injections are provided by the respective District Medical Officers (DMOs) to the Vandematharam doctors or clinics for free distribution to beneficiaries. Cases needing special care and treatment can be referred to government hospitals.

11th of April is being observed as the National Safe Motherhood Day in India.

questions.text: Day light factor in kitchens should be
questions.solution:
• Day light factor in kitchens should be 10%.
  • Day light factor is the measure of intensity of day light illumination.
  • Measured by Daylight Factor Meter.
  • Day light factor in kitchens should be 10% and in living rooms should be 8%.

Day light factor = (Instaneous illumination Indoors/ Simultaneously occuring illumination outdoors) x 100

questions.text: In UNICEF’s GOBI FFF strategy, the ‘O’ stands for?
questions.solution:
• The GOBI FFF strategy is aimed at child health revolution and survival.
  • Initially it was only called GOBI strategy and later the FFF aspect was added to it.
  • This strategy was proposed by the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF):
    • G– Growth monitoring with growth charts
    • O– Oral rehydration therapy for diarrhea and dehydration
    • B– Breastfeeding
    • I– Immunization of children
    • F– Family planning and birth spacing
    • F– Food supplementation
    • F­– Female literacy promotion

questions.text: Potential support ratio (PSR) is defined as:

choices.text: Number of persons aged 15 to 64 per children below 15 years
Number of persons aged 15 to 64 per older person aged more than 65 years and younger person less than 15 years
Number of persons aged 15 to 64 per older persons aged more than 60 and younger than 15 years
Number of persons aged 15 to 64 per one older person aged more than equal to 65 years

questions.solution:
Potential support ratio is the inverse of old age dependency ratio.

  • It is the number of people aged 15-64 per person aged 65 or older.
  • This ratio describes the burden placed on the working population by the non working elderly populaiton.
  • The unemployed and children are not considered in this measure.

questions.text: Bangalore method is a form of:
questions.solution:
Bangalore method is a type of anaerobic composting method of waste disposal.

Methods of refuse disposal:

  • Dumping: Refuse is dumped into low lying areas by throwing it in open space.
  • Controlled tipping:
    • Most satisfactory method of refuse disposal (sanitary landfill).
    • Includes 3 methods:
      • Trench method
      • Ramp method
      • Area method
  • Incineration: It is method of choice of disposal by burning when suitable land is not available.
  • Composting:
    • This is a method of combined disposal of refuse and sludge.
    • Compost has manorial value for soil.
    • It includes 2 methods:
      • Bangalore method - Anaerobic composting
      • Indore method - Aerobic mechanical composting
  • Manure pits: Commonly used in rural areas in India.
  • Burial: Suitable for small camps.

questions.text: PERT is used for:
questions.solution:
• PERT- Program Evaluation and Review Technique.
  • It is a type of network analysis. Network Analysis in Health Management.
  • A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective.
  • Two types of network analysis: PERT and CPM. 

Program Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT).

  • An arrow diagram of all events in logical sequence is drawn.
  • With this, time to finish each activity can be calculated and also critical activities can be identified.
  • It aids in planning, scheduling and monitoring of the project.

Critical Path Method (CPM):

  • The longest path of the network is called the critical path.
  • A delay in the critical path will cause a delay in the entire project.

questions.text: All of the following nutrients are present in egg except
questions.solution:
Egg contains all nutrients except Carbohydrates and Vitamin C.

A 60 gm egg contains:

  • 6 g Fat
  • 6 g Protein
  • 30 mg Calcium
  • 1.5 mg Iron
  • 70 Kcal Energy

The cholesterol content is 250 mg/ egg. Egg protein has all 9 Amino acids needed for the body in the right proportions and hence it is considered as "Reference Protein".

Net Protein Utilization (NPU) of an egg is 94, meat is 80, milk is 75. Boiled egg is nutritionally superior to raw egg. Boiling destroys avidin, a substance that prevents the body from absorbing Biotin.

questions.text: Anemometer is used for measuring:
questions.solution:
Anemometer is used to measure air velocity.

Instruments used in measurements include:

  • Anemometer- Air velocity
  • Wet globe thermometer- Environmental heat
  • Kata thermometer- Cooling power of air
  • Globe thermometer- Mean radiant temperature
  • Air humidity:
    • Dry and wet bulb thermometers
    • Hygrometer
    • Sling/ Whirling Psychrometer
    • Assman Psychrometer

questions.text: The ‘3 million’ plan was proposed by which health planning committee?
questions.solution:
• Key person in Bhore committee– Sir Joseph Bhore in 1946.
  • 3 million plans was the long term plan of the committee to set up primary health units with 75 bedded hospitals for 10,000 to 20,000 population, secondary units with 650 beds and district hospitals with 2,500 beds.
  • As a short term plan, the committee stated that each PHC must cater to 40,000 people and have 2 medical officers, 4 public health nurses, one nurse, 4 midwives, 4 dais, 2 sanitary inspectors, 2 health assistants, one pharmacist and 15 other class IV employees.

questions.text: In triage, yellow color indicates:
questions.solution:
Yellow color indicates medium priority in Triage.

The principle of first come first served is not followed in mass emergencies. Triage is rapidly classifying the injured based on the severity of injuries and likelihood of their survival with prompt medical intervention.

Four color code system:

  • Red: High priority
  • Yellow: Medium priority
  • Green: Ambulatory priority
  • Black: Dead or moribund patients

Triage should be carried out at the site of the disaster.

questions.text: Hard tick is the major vector of all the following diseases except
questions.solution:
Relapsing fever is majorly transmitted by soft tick (Ornithodorus).

Diseases transmitted by hard Tick Diseases transmitted by soft Tick

Tick typhus (RMSF)

Viral encephalitis

Tick fevers

Hemorrhagic fevers (KFD)

Tularaemia

Tick paralysis

Human babesiosis

Q fever (few animal cases)

Relapsing fever

questions.text: Multipurpose health worker scheme in India was introduced by which committee’s recommendation?
questions.solution:
Kartar Singh Committee was also called The Committee on Multipurpose Workers under Health and Family Planning.

Related Pearl: Health Planning Committees of India

Year

Name

Concepts and Programmes

1946

Bhore committee
  • Also called Health Survey and Development Committee
  • 1 PHC for 40,000 population
  • 3 million plan
  • 3 months training in PSM for physicians
  • Preventive and curative services at all administrative levels 

1962

Mudaliar committee
  • Also known as Health Survey and Planning Committee
  • District hospitals to have specialists
  • 1 PHC for not more than 40,000 people
  • Constitution of All India Health Service

1963

Chadah committee
  • Outlined responsibility of PHCs in the National Malaria Eradication Programme
  • One basic health worker for 10,000 population 

1965

Mukerji committee
  • Delinked malaria activities from family planning activities.
  • Family planning assistants were for family planning work and basic health workers for other activities.

1966

Mukerji committee
  • Also called committee of Health Secretaries.
  • Detailed the Basic Health Service to be given at block level 

1967

Jungalwalla committee
  • Also called Committee on Integration of Health Services
  • Ban of private practice by government doctors
  • Equal pay for equal work and special pay for specialized work

1973

Kartar Singh committee
  • Also called Committee on Multipurpose Workers under Health and Family Planning
  • Recommended male and female health workers
  • 1 PHC for 50,000 population
  • Each PHC to have 16 sub-centres
  • Each sub-centre to have one male and one female health worker

1975

Shrivastav committee
  • Also called Group on Medical Education and Support Manpower
  • Referral Services Complex
  • Rural Health Infrastructure of Sub centre, PHC and CHC
  • ROME scheme – Reorientation of health education
  • Establishment of Medical and Health Education Commission
  • Village Health Guide scheme
  • Bands of semi–professional and Para-professional Health workers 

1983

Krishnan committee

 
  • Urban Revamping Scheme
  • Integration of PHC       

1986

Bajaj committee
  • Formulation of National Medical and Health Education Policy.
  • Formulation of National Manpower Policy.
  • Health Manpower cells
  • Education commission.

questions.text: X chromosome is classified under which group?
questions.solution:
The chromosomes have been classified on the basis of length and certain morphological similarities into 7 groups.

Classification of Chromosomes:

  • A: 1–3
  • B: 4, 5
  • C: 6–12, X chromosome
  • D: 13–15
  • E: 16–18
  • F: 19, 20
  • G: 21, 22, Y chromosome

questions.text: Paris green is a:
questions.solution:
Paris green is a stomach poison.

Paris Green (Copper Acetoarsenite):

  • Emerald green, microcrystalline powder
  • Anti-larval measure
  • Kills mainly Anopheles larvae as they are surface feeders
  • Bottom feeding larvae can also be killed, when applied as a special granular formulation.
  • Paris green is a stomach poison.
  • It is most widely used larvicide for mosquito control.
  • Recommended dose: 1 kg Paris green per hectare water surface.
  • In dosage applied Paris green does not harm fish, man or domestic animals.

Contact poison- Pyrethrum, DDT

Space poison- Fumigants like hydrogen cyanide

questions.text: Which of the following is not among the pillars of primary health care?
questions.solution: Principles of primary health care include equitable distribution, community participation, intersectoral coordination and appropriate technology.

questions.text: Catch-up, keep-up and follow-up is the WHO's elimination strategy for?
questions.solution:
The WHO Measles elimination strategy involves Catch-up, Keep-up and Follow-up.

Catch-up:

  • One time nationwide vaccination campaign targeting all children aged 9 months - 14 years regardless of history of measles disease or vaccination status.

Keep-up:

  • Routine services aimed at vaccinating 95% of each successive birth cohort.

Follow-up:

  • Subsequent nationwide vaccination conducted every 2-4 years targetting usually all children born after the Catch-up campaign.

questions.text: Vectors do not transmit infection by
questions.solution:
Vectors do not transmit infection by ingestion.

Methods of transmission of infection by vectors are:

  • Biting
  • Regurgitation
  • Scratching or rubbing of infected feces
  • Contamination of host with body fluids of vectors

questions.text: Which of the following is not the work of an Anganwadi worker?
questions.solution:
Services provided through ICDS scheme Anganwadi workers:

  • Supplementary nutrition
  • Infant & Young Child feeding (IYCF) Promotion & Counselling
  • Immunization
  • Referral Non formal preschool education
  • Health education
  • Health check up
  • Vitamin A prophylaxis
  • Weekly iron and folic acid tablets
  • Deworming
  • Maintenance of growth chart

questions.text: A pregnant woman from a rural area registers under Janani Suraksha Yojana. Which of the following services would not be provided to her under this scheme?

choices.text: Safe motherhood services under Vandematharam scheme

questions.solution:
The Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) does not provide STD counseling.

Janani Suraksha Yojana is a safe motherhood intervention launched under National Rural Health Mission (NRHM) to reduce maternal and neonatal mortality by promoting institutional delivery among poor pregnant women. The services provided by the JSY are:

  • Cash is disbursed to the mother at the institution for having an institutional delivery.
  • Safe motherhood services (IFA tablets, TT vaccination) under the Vandemataram scheme. 
  • Village health and nutrition day
  • Maternal death review
  • Pregnancy tracking: ASHA worker/Anganwadi Worker (AWW) or any other link worker help in monitoring antenatal check-ups, and post-delivery care.
  • Safe abortion services: mifepristone followed by misoprostol and manual vacuum aspiration.

questions.text: You are a researcher conducting a study in an urban young population regarding skin melanoma. You formulate a hypothesis on etiology. Which of the following studies is used for formulating an etiological hypothesis?
questions.solution:
A descriptive study is used for formulating an etiological hypothesis.

Descriptive statistics is a type of statistical method which helps to describe, organise or summarise the data. It refers only to the actual data.

Descriptive studies are limited to the description of a disease, including its etiology, pathogenesis, and occurrence, in a population. Diseases of unknown etiology or new diseases can be studied with descriptive epidemiology. There is no intervention in this type of study. it is merely observational.

It involves the following: 

  • Defining the study population 
  • Defining the disease under the study
  • Describing the disease by parameters like time, place and person
  • Measuring the disease
  • Comparing it with known indices and
  • Formulating an etiological hypothesis.

The formulated hypothesis should specify the following:   

  • The study population 
  • The cause which is taken into consideration
  • Expected outcome
  • Dose-response relationship
  • Time-response relationship

Types of epidemiological studies:

Observational studies - allow nature to take its own course, the investigator measures but does not intervene.

  1. Descriptive studies - limited to the description of the occurrence of a disease in a population.
  2. Analytical studies - go further by analysing the relationship between health status and other variables.
    • Ecological studies
    • Cross-sectional studies
    • Case-control studies
    • Cohort studies

Experimental studies or intervention studies involve an active attempt to change a disease determinant or the progress of a disease and are similar in design to experiments in other sciences.

  1. Randomized controlled trials
  2. Field trials
  3. Community trials      

Other options:

Option A: Analytical study is a type of epidemiological study and its objective is to test the hypothesis. 

Option B: Experimental studies involve making changes in the experimental group while no changes are made in the control group and comparing the outcome. 

Option C: A cross-sectional study or prevalence study is a form of observational study. A cross-section of the population at one point in time is examined and it reflects the results of the whole population. 

Related Pearl: Descriptive Epidemiology

Descriptive Epidemiology

  • Descriptive studies are used to describe a disease of unknown etiology.
  • Steps
    • Defining the population to be studied
    • Defining the disease to be studied
    • Describing the disease by time, place, and person
      • Measurement of the disease by cross sectional or longitudinal study
      • Comparing with known indices
      • Formulation of an etiological hypothesis
  • Uses
    • Provides data of magnitude of disease load in community
    • Provides clues to disease etiology
    • Provides background data for health planning
    • Contributes to research by describing the disease

Related Pearl: Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

The flow chart below gives a glance into the types of epidemiological study designs and where they are generally used.

Note: Descripitve study is used to formulate aetiological hypothesis of a disease. Whereas analytical study is used to test the hypothesis (i.e to accept or reject the hypothesis).

questions.text: If the annual growth rate of a population is 1.0-1.5, number of years required to double the population size is:
questions.solution:
Annual growth rate exclusive of migration is when crude death rate is subtracted from the crude birth rate.

  • World population growth rate is 1.2 (2014).
  • A population growing at a rate of 0.5% will double in 140 years and a population growing at a rate of 3% will double in 20-25 years.
Rating Annual growth rate % No. of years for population doubling
Stationary population No growth -
Slow growth Lesss than 0.5   More than 139
Moderate growth 0.5-1  70-139
Rapid growth 1-1.5  47-70
Very rapid 1.5-2  35-47
Explosive growth

2-2.5

2.5-3

3-3.5

3.5-4 

28-35

23-28

20-23

18-20

questions.text: Tracking of BP implies
questions.solution:
Tracking of BP:

If the BP of individuals were followed up over a period of years, the low BP levels tend to remain low and high BP level tends to become higher as the individual grows older. This phenomenon of persistence of rank order of BP is implied as Tracking of BP.

questions.text: All of the following are advantages of the case-control study except?
questions.solution:
Incidence of a disease cannot be calculated from a case-control study.

Advantages of case-control study:

  • Simple to conduct
  • Less time consuming
  • Less expensive
  • No problem in follow up/drop out (attrition)
  • Suitable for rare diseases
  • Multiple types of exposure causing a single disease can be studied
  • The odds ratio can be obtained

Disadvantages of case-control:

  • Bias is present- Either recall or selection bias
  • The temporality of association cannot be determined
  • The natural history of the disease cannot be studied
  • Incidence, relative risk, and attributable risk cannot be calculated

questions.text: Toxin which causes endemic ascites?
questions.solution:
The weed seeds of Crotalaria contain Pyrrozolidine alkaloids that are hepatotoxic. The millet Panicum Millaire gets adultered or contaminated with weed seeds of Crotalaria and produce symptoms of endemic Ascites which is rapidly developing ascites and Jaundice. Edemic ascites was reported in Surguja disctrict of Madhya Pradesh in 1973 and in Nagesia tribals in 1976.

Preventive measures:

  • Sieving of millets at home
  • Deweeding of Jhunjhunia plants
  • Health education

questions.text: At a metabolic disorder camp conducted by a PHC, the intern forgets to measure the patient's height. Which obesity index can still be accurately assessed despite this omission?
questions.solution:
Corpulence index= Actual weight/ Desirable weight

It is the index of obesity that is not dependent on height, hence obesity index may be measured using this index excluding height.

Assessment of obesity:

  • Quetelet index (BMI)= Weight (kg)/ Height2 (m)
  • Ponderal index= Height (cm)/ Cube root of body weight(kg)
  • Broca index= Height (cm)- 100
  • Lorentz formula= Height (cm)- 100 - {Height(cm)-150/2(women) or 4(men)}
  • Corpulence index= Actual weight/ Desirable weight

questions.text: The heart of RCT is:
questions.solution:
• Randomization is a statistical procedure wherein the population is grouped into study and control groups.
  • It is done so to know whether any intervention is needed to be given or not.
  • This is done to reduce the bias and to allow comparability between the individuals.

questions.text: Rotary kilns are used to dispose
questions.solution:
Rotatory kilns are incinerators, used to dispose off:

  • Anatomical waste (human, animal)
  • Soiled waste
  • Expired or discarded medicines
  • Discarded linen, mattress or bedding contaminated with body fluid

questions.text: Disease not included in vision 2020 India is:
questions.solution:
Vision 2020 includes all diseases given above except onchocercariasis.

  • Vision 2020: Right to sight.
  • The target diseases included in vision 2020 India:
    • Cataract
    • Refractive errors
    • Childhood blindness
    • Corneal blindness
    • Glaucoma
    • Diabetic retinopathy

questions.text: All of the following are types of didactic method of communication except
questions.solution:
• Didactic method is one way communication.
  • Disadvantages are:
    • Knowledge is imposed on the person
    • Does not change the behavior of the patient
    • No feedback
  • Eg. lecture method, newspaper, radio and television

questions.text: Chandler index of 350 indicates

choices.text: Hookworm infection is not of much significance
Hookworm infection regarded as potential danger
Hookworm infection – a minor public health problem
Hookworm infection – an important public health problem

questions.solution:
Chandler index is the average number of hookworm eggs per gram of stools.

Chandler Index   Indication  
Below 200  Hookworm infection is not of much significance  
200 – 250   May be regarded as potential danger  
250 – 300   Minor public health problem  
Above 300   Important public health problem  

Uses of Chandler Index:

  • Worm loads in different population groups can be compared.
  • Degree of reduction of egg output after mass treatment can be seen.
  • Clay soils are most favorable for development of Ascaris eggs.
  • Moist porous soils are favorable for hookworm eggs.
  • Ancylostoma duodenale is prevalent in North India and Necator americans in South India.
  • Rhabditiform larvae moults twice in the soil.
  • Larvae of A.duodenale are also infective by mouth.

questions.text: Glycosylated haemoglobin reflects the mean blood glucose level of previous
questions.solution:
• HbA1C reflects mean blood glucose level for past 2-3 months.
  • Glycosylated Hb: It should be estimated atleast at half yearly intervals.
  • It provides a long term index of glucose control for the past 2-3 months.

questions.text: All of the following are principles of health education except
questions.solution:
Principles of Health Education:

  • Interest
  • Credibility
  • Motivation
  • Feedback
  • Leadership
  • Comprehension
  • Known to unknown
  • Setting an example
  • Reinforcement
  • Learning by doing
  • Participation
  • Good human relation

questions.text: Under international drinking water supply and sanitation decade programme 1981, which of the following targets was not stipulated?

choices.text: 100% coverage for water for urban and rural

questions.solution:
International Drinking Water Supply and Sanitation Decade Programme– 1981 targets:

  • 100% coverage for water in both urban and rural
  • 80% for urban sanitation
  • 25% for rural sanitation

Stipulated norm of water supply:

  • 40 Litres of safe drinking water per capita per day
  • One hand pump or spot source for every 250 persons

questions.text: The present day strategy of initial screening of women for cervical cancer is:

choices.text: Visual inspection after application of freshly prepared solution 5% acetic acid solution

questions.solution:
• The present day strategy of initial screening of women for cervical cancer is by visual inspection after application of freshly prepared solution 5% acetic acid solution.
  • Detection of well defined circum- orificial acetowhite areas or ulceroproliferative growth on the cervix will provide VIA or VIAM positive.
  • In the district hospital treatment should be based on single visit colposcopy approach.
  • Biopsy and Pap smear are done to ensure that there are cytological and histological backup for the interventions.

questions.text: Categorical data can be represented by all the following except
questions.solution:
• Qualitative data or categorical data is represented by:
    • Bar graph
    • Spot map
    • Pie chart/ pictograph
  • Quantitative data or numerical data is represented by:
    • Histogram
    • Line diagram
    • Scatter plot
    • Frequency polygon

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Pradhan mantri poshan shakti nirman?

choices.text: It is a centrally sponsored scheme aimed at addressing hunger and education
Cooked meal is provided only to preschool children
Objective is to make children attend school regularly
It is provided in government and government aided schools

questions.solution:
Pradhan mantri poshan shakti nirman (PM POSHAN) is a centrally sponsored scheme that provides cooked meals for preschool children and children up to standard VIII

The main objective is to improve hunger and education by 

  • providing hot-cooked meals in government and government-aided schools.
  • attend school more regularly and concentrate on school activities.

questions.text: MCH care is assessed by
questions.solution:
The commonly used mortality indicators of MCH care:

  • Maternal mortality ratio
  • Mortality in infancy and childhood:
    • Perinatal mortality rate
    • Postnatal mortality rate
    • Neonatal mortality rate
    • Infant mortality rate
    • 1-4 year mortality rate
    • Under 5 mortality rate
    • Child survival rate

questions.text: Which of the following can have more than one value?
questions.solution:
• Mode is the most frequently occurring value in data distribution.
  • May be multiple like bimodal or trimodal.
  • Advantages:
    • Easy to understand and unaffected by extreme values.
  • Disadvantages:
    • Exact location is uncertain and is often not clearly defined.
    • It is not used in biological or medical studies.

questions.text: Index which is an indicator of potential explosiveness of plague outbreak?
questions.solution:
Commonest and most effective vector of plague is X. cheopis.

Cheopis index:

  • Average number of X. cheopis/ rat
  • If the index is more than 1, it is regarded as a potential explosiveness of plague outbreak.

Partially blocked flea is more dangerous than a completely blocked flea because it can live longer.

questions.text: Ujjawala scheme is for prevention of
questions.solution:
Ujjawala scheme is for prevention of child trafficking.

Ujjawala scheme:

  • It is a comprehensive scheme to combat trafficking was launched in India by the Ministry of Women and Child Development on 4 th December 2007.
  • It is being implemented mainly through NGOs.

5 Components:

  • Prevention
  • Rescue
  • Rehabilitation
  • Reintegration
  • Repatriation

Provisions:

  • Formation of community vigilance groups.
  • Safe withdrawal of victims from the place of exploitation.
  • Rehabilitation of the victims by providing basic provisions.
  • Reintegration of victims into society.
  • Provide support to cross border victims for their safe repatriation to the country of origin.

questions.text: What phase of the demographic cycle has low birth rate and death rate?
questions.solution:
• Birth rate and death rate are low and they cancel each other.
  • It is the 4 th phase of the demographic cycle.
  • Population fails to grow.
  • Demographic gap is 0.
  • Eg. Australia, UK, Denmark, Belgium and Sweden.

questions.text: All are included in Kangaroo Mother Care except?
questions.solution:
Free nutritional supplementation does not come under Kangaroo Mother Care. Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) was introduced for the prevention of neonatal hypothermia in low birth weight/ premature newborns. It was first introduced by Dr. Hector Martinez and Dr. Edzar Ray in Columbia in 1979. It has 4 components—

  • Skin-to-skin positioning of newborn on mother’s chest.
  • Adequate nutrition through breast feeding.
  • Early discharge and ambulatory care.
  • Support for mother and family for child care.

Evidence shows that-

  • KMC works as well as an incubator for safety and thermal protection
  • Improves breastfeeding rates
  • Severe comorbidities are reduced
  • Better bonding between mother and baby

questions.text: Disability limitation belongs to which level of prevention of disease?
questions.solution:
Disability limitation belongs to tertiary prevention.

  • The levels of prevention are primordial, primary, secondary, and tertiary.
  • Tertiary prevention includes disability limitation and rehabilitation.
  • It is done when the disease has reached advanced stages and aims to limit impairments.

questions.text: As of 2012 statistics, which of the following is not a polio endemic country?
questions.solution:
Bangladesh was not a polio endemic country as per the 2012 statistics.

In 2012, there were only 3 Polio Endemic countries:

  • Afghanistan
  • Pakistan
  • Nigeria

As of 25 th February 2012, India was removed from the list of Polio endemic countries by the World Health Organization (WHO).

  • The Regional Certification commission certifies a region polio-free when the following 3 conditions are met:
    • The absence of indigenous Wild Polio Virus (WPV) transmission for at least 3 consecutive years, monitored by a sensitive, certification-standard surveillance system.
    • The capacity to detect, report, and rapidly respond to any imported WPV.
    • Documentation of substantial progress toward the eventual laboratory containment (at an appropriate biosafety level) of WPV.
  • The World Health Organisation (WHO) presented official certification to India for its ‘Polio Free’ status on March 27 th 2014.
  • This achievement makes the South-East Asia Region, the fourth WHO Region to be certified as polio-free, after the Region of the Americas in 1994, the Western Pacific Region in 2000 and the European Region in 2002.

questions.text: ‘Lead time’ refers to the time between:

choices.text: Disease onset and first critical diagnosis
Disease onset and first possible point of detection
First possible point of detection and final critical point
First possible point of detection and usual time of diagnosis

questions.solution:
Lead time:

  • Period between the first possible time of detection and the actual time of diagnosis.
  • Lead time is the advantage gained by screening.
  • Early detection of disease will ensure earlier institution of treatment, thus better prognosis.

questions.text: Malaria is an example of what kind of biological transmission of arthropod diseases?
questions.solution:
Biological transmission of arthropod diseases:

  • Propagative- Disease agent only multiplies in the vector. Eg. Yellow fever, plague
  • Cyclopropagative- Disease agent multiplies and cyclical changes occurs. Eg. Malaria
  • Cyclodevelopmental- Only cyclical changes occur in the vector. Eg. Filarial, guineaworm
  • Transstadial transmission- Disease agent is transmitted from the nymph to the adult. Eg. B. burgdorferi
  • Trans-overian transmission- Disease agent is transmitted via the eggs from one generation to the other. Eg. R. ricketsia

questions.text: In India, prevalence of leprosy per 10000 cases in 2012 is:
questions.solution:
In India, the prevalence rate for Leprosy is 0.68 per 10000 population in 2012.

  • In India, the annual new case detection rate (ANCDR) for Leprosy is 1 per 10000 population.
  • Relapse rate is one of the best indicators of efficiency of drug regimen.

questions.text: All of the following are minimum standards for sanitation of schools and its environment in India except:

choices.text: Combined doors + windows area = 25 % of floor space area
One urinal for 10 students and one latrine for 25 students

questions.solution:
One urinal per 60 students and one latrine per 100 students is the standard.

Healthful school environment: Suggested minimum standards for sanitation of schools and its environment in India includes:

  • Location: Away from noisy surroundings; kept fenced.
  • Site: 5 acres for primary schools; 10 acres for higher elementary schools.
  • Structure: Exterior walls 10 inch thick and heat resistant.
  • Class room: 1 class room per 40 students maximum; Per capita space > 10 sq. feet
  • Furniture: Single desks of ‘minus (–) type’.
  • Doors and windows: Doors and windows area> 25% of floor area
  • Color: Inside color of walls should be white.
  • Lighting: Natural light from left side.
  • Water supply: Safe and potable and continuous supply through taps.
  • Lavatory: 1 urinal per 60 students and 1 latrine per 100 students.

questions.text: Mission Indradhanush includes vaccination against the following except:
questions.solution:
Mission Indradhanush:

  • It aims to cover the vaccination against 7 diseases by 2020.
  • Immunization against:
    • Tuberculosis
    • Polio
    • Diphtheria
    • Pertussis
    • Tetanus
    • Measles
    • Hepatitis B
  • Strategy used is the catch up campaign to cover those children who have been missed.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in ‘5 cleans’ in conduct of delivery?

choices.text: Clean cutting and care of cord

questions.solution:
Clean perineum is not a criteria.

Clean of safe delivery:

‘Five cleans’ (practices) under strategies for elimination of neonatal tetanus include:

  • Clean delivery surface
  • Clean hands (of birth attendants)
  • Clean cord cut (blade or instrument)
  • Clean cord tie
  • Clean cord stump (no applicant)

questions.text: Maternal mortality ratio (MMR) is expressed as:
questions.solution:
• Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR): Number of maternal deaths during a given time period per 100,000 live births during the same time period.

NOTE: Maternal Mortality Rate: Number of maternal deaths during a given time period per 100,000 women of reproductive age in the same time period.

 

MMR =( No. of maternal deaths in a given year/ Total no. of live births in the same year ) x 100,000

Maternal death is defined as:

  • Death of a woman while pregnant.
  • During delivery or within 42 days (6 weeks) of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of duration or site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.
